questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. His height and development are within 50th percentile. What is the most appropriate expected weight for the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 16 kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The expected weight of a child at 4 years old is approximately 16 kg when the child is within the 50th percentile for height and development.
  • ➤ 16 kg

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is referred to a pediatric clinic for evaluation due to concerns about his growth. During the assessment, the healthcare provider uses an instrument shown in the image. What aspect of growth this instrument is used to measure?

options.label: A
options.text: Harpenden calliper for skin fold thickness

questions.correct_answer: A. Harpenden calliper for skin fold thickness
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Harpenden calliper for skin fold thickness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Harpenden caliper is specifically used to measure skinfold thickness , which is an essential parameter for assessing body fat composition and nutritional status in children.
  • ➤ Harpenden caliper
  • ➤ skinfold thickness

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents for a well-baby check-up. During previous visits, the head circumference was below the normal range, his birth head circumference was 33 cm. What is the expected head circumference for the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 39 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The head circumference of an infant typically increases by 2 cm per month during the first three months of life. Therefore, the head circumference at three months is expected to be 39 cm when starting from a birth measurement of 33 cm.
  • ➤ 2 cm per month
  • ➤ 39 cm

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to parental concern about her height. On further examination it was found that the child's height has been doubled from the birth length. What is the expected height of the baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 100cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The expected height of a 4-year-old child is 100 cm , which is double the average birth length (50 cm) and follows standard growth benchmarks.
  • ➤ 4-year-old child
  • ➤ 100 cm

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with down syndrome presents to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The parents express concerns about their child's health and inquire about potential medical characteristics associated with down syndrome. During the discussion, the pediatrician mentions that individuals with down syndrome may experience certain variations in health compared to the general population. In this context, the pediatrician asks, "in down syndrome, which of the following is decreased?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha feto protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Down syndrome, Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is decreased, while Beta-HCG and Inhibin A levels are elevated. Prenatal screening tests use these markers to identify the likelihood of chromosomal abnormalities.
  • ➤ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • ➤ Beta-HCG
  • ➤ Inhibin A

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child is brought to the genetics clinic due to developmental delays and distinctive facial features. Upon further investigation, a chromosomal analysis reveals a karyotype of 47, xxy. The genetic counselor discusses the findings with the parents and poses the question, "identify the syndrome in this male child with the following karyotype?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Down

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Down syndrome, or Trisomy 21, is identified by the presence of three chromosomes on the 21st pair in the karyotype. It is associated with developmental delays, distinctive facial features, and congenital health conditions.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for a routine well-baby checkup. The physician conducts a thorough physical examination, paying special attention to the fontanelles, the soft spots on the infant's skull. The parents, eager to understand their child's development, ask, "which of the fontanelles is the last to close?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior fontanelle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close, typically between 8 and 18 months of age, making it a key feature for assessing an infant’s skull development and growth.
  • ➤ anterior fontanelle
  • ➤ 8 and 18 months

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician due to concerns raised by his parents about developmental delays and peculiar physical characteristics. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes a distinctive facial appearance, characterized by almond-shaped eyes, a flattened nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease. The infant displays poor muscle tone, and infant's tongue protrudes slightly. On further examination patient had premature fusion of coronal suture. What is the most common finding associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bracychephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brachycephaly is the most common skull deformity associated with premature fusion of the coronal suture . It results in a shortened front-to-back skull with compensatory widening.
  • ➤ Brachycephaly
  • ➤ coronal suture

questions.text: During a routine pediatric examination, a 10-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by concerned parents who have noticed an unusual head shape. Upon careful inspection, the pediatrician observes an abnormality in the sagittal suture, characterized by a noticeable overlap of the cranial bones. The parents express worry, prompting the pediatrician to discuss the potential consequences of this sagittal suture overlapping. What does sagital suture overlapping cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dolichocephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dolichocephaly (also known as scaphocephaly ) results from sagittal suture overlapping or premature fusion. It leads to a long and narrow skull shape due to restricted lateral growth and compensatory elongation.
  • ➤ Dolichocephaly
  • ➤ scaphocephaly

questions.text: During a prenatal counseling session, a soon-to-be mother expresses concerns about her recent alcohol consumption during early pregnancy. The obstetrician emphasizes the potential risks and complications associated with prenatal alcohol exposure, underscoring the importance of avoiding alcohol intake during pregnancy. The mother, anxious about the well-being of her unborn child, inquiries about the specific features and complications encompassed by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). The component associated with fetal alcohol syndrome are?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) includes a triad of features:
  • ➤ Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)
  • ➤ Facial abnormalities (e.g., short palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum). Growth retardation (e.g., microcephaly). Neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., hearing impairment, cognitive delays).
  • ➤ Facial abnormalities (e.g., short palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum).
  • ➤ Facial abnormalities
  • ➤ Growth retardation (e.g., microcephaly).
  • ➤ Growth retardation
  • ➤ Neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., hearing impairment, cognitive delays).
  • ➤ Neurodevelopmental disorders
  • ➤ Avoiding alcohol consumption during pregnancy is the most effective way to prevent FAS.

questions.text: In the context of pediatric care, a concerned parent approaches a healthcare provider seeking guidance on the appropriate method for measuring their toddler's temperature. The healthcare provider takes this opportunity to educate the parent about the various methods available and their respective applications. When discussing axillary temperature measurement, the healthcare provider asks the parent that for how long a thermometer is kept for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When using a standard mercury thermometer, axillary temperature measurement requires the thermometer to be kept in place for 3 minutes to ensure accuracy.
  • ➤ 3 minutes

questions.text: In the neonatal ward, a team of healthcare providers is conducting rounds, and a new resident expresses interest in understanding the distinguishing factors between physiological and pathological jaundice in newborns. The senior pediatrician seizes the teaching moment and initiates a discussion on the criteria that help differentiate between these two types of jaundice. During the discourse, the pediatrician poses the question that which of the following is not a criterion of pathological jaundice?

options.label: C
options.text: More than 2 mg / dl conjugated bilirubin

questions.correct_answer: A. 24 hours later but within 72 hrs
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 24 hours later but within 72 hrs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jaundice appearing after 24 hours and resolving within 72 hours is physiological , whereas jaundice within 24 hours , lasting beyond 14 days , or associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and clay-colored stool is pathological .
  • ➤ after 24 hours and resolving within 72 hours
  • ➤ physiological
  • ➤ within 24 hours
  • ➤ beyond 14 days
  • ➤ conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and clay-colored stool
  • ➤ pathological

questions.text: During a routine developmental assessment in a pediatric clinic, a concerned parent raises questions about their child's language development and cognitive milestones. The pediatrician takes the opportunity to provide guidance on age-appropriate developmental expectations. Language development is a crucial aspect of a child's cognitive growth. By what age milestone can a typically developing child be expected to accurately tell their age, name, and gender?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 3-year-old child is typically able to state their name , age , and gender , reflecting an important milestone in language and cognitive development.
  • ➤ 3-year-old child
  • ➤ name
  • ➤ age
  • ➤ gender

questions.text: In the context of forensic pediatrics, where age determination plays a critical role, a medical examiner is approached by law enforcement officials regarding the assessment of an unidentified child's age, possibly a victim of human trafficking. The medical examiner takes this opportunity to educate the officials about the appropriate radiological approach for age estimation in infants. During the discussion, the medical examiner poses the following question: which is the best x ray of bone age estimation for a 10-month-old baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) X ray shoulder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For age estimation in infants aged 3 months to 1 year , the X-ray of the shoulder is the most reliable tool due to the ossification patterns observed in this region.
  • ➤ 3 months to 1 year
  • ➤ X-ray of the shoulder

questions.text: In a bustling pediatric clinic, a 6-month-old child is brought in by concerned parents who have noticed peculiar physical features. Parents who have noticed a concerning rash on their child's skin accompanied by irritability and feeding difficulties. The dermatologist, recognizing the distinctive features of the skin condition, initiates a discussion with the parents to enhance their understanding of the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Slc39a4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acrodermatitis enteropathica is caused by a mutation in the SLC39A4 gene, leading to impaired intestinal zinc absorption. Prompt diagnosis and zinc supplementation are crucial for resolving symptoms and preventing complications.
  • ➤ Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  • ➤ SLC39A4

questions.text: In the high-stakes environment of the neonatal intensive care unit (nicu), a team of healthcare professionals is conducting a simulated scenario involving the resuscitation of a newborn. As the scenario unfolds, the team encounters a moment of uncertainty regarding the initiation of chest compressions. To ensure optimal outcomes, it's crucial to know when to initiate chest compressions. Can you identify the specific indications for the initiation of chest compressions in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hr<60

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions are indicated when the heart rate is less than 60 bpm despite effective ventilation with 100% oxygen for at least 30 seconds.
  • ➤ chest compressions
  • ➤ heart rate is less than 60 bpm

questions.text: In a prenatal counselling session, a pregnant woman expresses concern about potential infectious risks to her unborn child and inquiries about the distinguishing features of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS). The obstetrician, keen on providing comprehensive information, takes this opportunity to delve into the specific characteristics of CRS. Can you identify which of the following is not a typical feature associated with CRS?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydrocephalus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is characterized by congenital heart disease (PDA) , deafness , and ocular abnormalities (e.g., cataracts). Hydrocephalus is not a feature of CRS but is commonly seen in congenital toxoplasmosis .
  • ➤ congenital heart disease (PDA)
  • ➤ deafness
  • ➤ ocular abnormalities
  • ➤ Hydrocephalus
  • ➤ toxoplasmosis

questions.text: In a dynamic emergency room setting, a team of healthcare professionals is engaged in the resuscitation of a critically ill patient. Recognizing the significance of clear communication and understanding of resuscitation principles, can you identify which of the following is the correct feature of resuscitation, and how does this element contribute to the overall effectiveness of the resuscitation process?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tickle the sole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tickling the sole is an effective, gentle technique for stimulating respiration in neonates and critically ill patients during resuscitation.

questions.text: In a public health seminar on neonatal healthcare in India, a group of healthcare professionals is discussing the critical factors influencing neonatal mortality rates in the country. Amidst the discussion, a junior paediatrician seeks clarification on the primary challenges contributing to neonatal mortality. "In the context of neonatal healthcare in India, understanding the leading causes of neonatal mortality is crucial for targeted interventions. Which is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prematurity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prematurity is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India, emphasizing the need for improved prenatal care and neonatal interventions to enhance outcomes for preterm infants.

questions.text: In a prenatal care workshop attended by expectant parents, the focus is on understanding the significance of various prenatal screenings and their role in identifying potential developmental concerns in the unborn child. During the workshop, a genetic counsellor initiates a discussion on neural tube defects (NTDS) and their detection. Which is the marker of neural tube defect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acetyl cholin esterase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) : The most specific marker for NTDs, detectable in amniotic fluid. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) : Sensitive marker for NTDs.
  • ➤ Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) : The most specific marker for NTDs, detectable in amniotic fluid.
  • ➤ Acetylcholinesterase (AChE)
  • ➤ most specific marker
  • ➤ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) : Sensitive marker for NTDs.
  • ➤ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

questions.text: In a bustling pediatric clinic, a mother brings in her 4-month-old infant for a routine check-up. During the appointment, the pediatrician discusses the importance of nutritional supplementation, particularly emphasizing the role of zinc in infant development. Recognizing the potential knowledge gap, the pediatrician seizes the opportunity to educate the mother further. "As we consider the nutritional needs of your 4-month-old infant, it's crucial to address the appropriate supplementation of essential minerals. What is the dose of zinc for the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10 mg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended dose of zinc supplementation for infants under 6 months is 10 mg per day, while for those older than 6 months, the dose is 20 mg per day. Zinc supplementation is typically given for 14 days during illness.

questions.text: In a pediatric neurology seminar, healthcare professionals are engaged in a discussion about congenital hydrocephalus, a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid within the brain's ventricles. The lead neurologist, aiming to assess the depth of understanding among the attendees, poses a thought-provoking question: what is not true regarding congenital hydrocephalus?

options.label: C
options.text: Broad forehead and wide-open anterior fontanelle

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mostly hereditery in nature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital hydrocephalus is mostly caused by structural abnormalities (e.g., aqueductal stenosis) or associated conditions like spina bifida, but it is not primarily hereditary.

questions.text: In a radiology conference focusing on pediatric imaging, a group of medical professionals, including radiologists and residents, are discussing various imaging findings indicative of congenital anomalies. "As we delve into the intriguing world of pediatric radiology, it's essential to recognize distinct imaging signs that point to specific congenital conditions. Where do you identify in which congenital anomaly the 'double bubble sign' is typically observed, and what underlying anatomical abnormality does this radiological finding signify?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "double bubble sign" is a hallmark radiological feature of duodenal atresia, resulting from a blockage between the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

questions.text: In a medical grand round’s presentation focusing on vaccine safety and adverse reactions, a seasoned infectious disease specialist addresses a diverse audience of healthcare professionals. "As we explore the intricacies of vaccine safety, it's imperative to be aware of potential adverse reactions that can arise. Osteomyelitis is a side effect of which vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BCG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteomyelitis is a rare adverse reaction associated with the BCG vaccine. It is essential to monitor patients for unusual symptoms post-vaccination, especially in immunocompromised individuals .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a concerned parent brings in their 8-year-old child who developed a sudden onset of facial redness, particularly on both cheeks. The parent, alarmed by the distinctive appearance, seeks clarification from the pediatrician. "During the examination of your child, the presence of a facial rash seen in the image was noted. Can you identify the specific viral infection associated with this distinctive clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Erythema infectiosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema infectiosum, caused by Parvovirus B19, presents with a distinctive "slapped cheek" rash and is a common, self-limiting condition in school-aged children.

questions.text: In a postnatal care unit, a new mother is seeking guidance from the lactation consultant regarding challenges with breastfeeding her newborn. The mother expresses concern about her baby's difficulty transitioning between breastfeeding and bottle-feeding. "During our discussion about breastfeeding and bottle-feeding practices, you mentioned that your newborn is experiencing nipple confusion. What is nipple confusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Baby not able to suck the bottle

options.label: D
options.text: Baby who was on bottle finding it difficult to suck the breast

questions.correct_answer: D. Baby who was on bottle finding it difficult to suck the breast
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Baby who was on bottle finding it difficult to suck the breast.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipple confusion describes a baby’s difficulty transitioning from bottle-feeding back to breastfeeding, as bottle-feeding requires different sucking techniques. Early establishment of breastfeeding can help prevent nipple confusion.

questions.text: In a pediatric dermatology clinic, a 6-month-old infant is brought in by concerned parents who have noticed skin abnormalities and feeding difficulties in their child. The dermatologist, suspecting a rare condition, initiates a conversation to delve into the underlying causes. Physical examination reveals periorificial and acral dermatitis. On further evaluation, baby had diarrhea with severe dehydration. Which of the following deficiency explained the given scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Periorificial and acral dermatitis, combined with diarrhea, is a hallmark of zinc deficiency. Timely diagnosis and zinc supplementation are crucial to prevent complications .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In a developmental assessment clinic, parents express concerns about their 4-year-old child's abilities and milestones compared to other children of the same age. The paediatrician, aiming to provide guidance and education, initiates a conversation with the parents. Considering your 4-year-old, can you identify which of the following tasks is generally beyond the developmental capabilities of a child at this age?

options.label: D
options.text: Can draw a straight a line

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Count 10 pennies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Counting 10 pennies is typically beyond the developmental capability of a 4-year-old child, as this skill develops closer to 5 years of age.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, parents bring in their 10-year-old daughter, expressing apprehension about her height, as she appears notably shorter than her classmates. "as we explore your daughter's growth patterns, it's essential to establish clear criteria for defining short stature in pediatric clinical practice. Can you identify the specific height threshold that generally characterizes 'short stature' in children?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3rdcentile

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Short stature in children is formally defined as a height below the 3rd centile or less than -2 standard deviations on a growth chart for their age and sex.
  • ➤ 3rd centile
  • ➤ less than -2 standard deviations

questions.text: In a prenatal education session, an expectant mother expresses her intention to breastfeed but seeks clarity on potential contraindications. The lactation consultant, recognizing the importance of informed decision-making, engages in a detailed discussion to address the mother's concerns. Which of the following identify potential contraindications to breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactosemia / lactose intolerance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absolute contraindications to breastfeeding include specific conditions like galactosemia in the infant. Other conditions, such as maternal infections (e.g., untreated tuberculosis or HIV), may require individual assessment and modifications but are not always absolute contraindications.
  • ➤ absolute contraindications
  • ➤ galactosemia

questions.text: In a breastfeeding support group, a new mother seeks clarification on certain aspects of breast milk to enhance her understanding of infant nutrition. Which of the following is a false information regarding breast feeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High lactoglobulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast milk is rich in lactalbumin, not lactoglobulin . It provides about 65 kcal per 100 ml , contains IgA for immune protection, and is naturally deficient in vitamin K , requiring supplementation for newborns.
  • ➤ rich in lactalbumin, not lactoglobulin
  • ➤ 65 kcal per 100 ml
  • ➤ IgA
  • ➤ deficient in vitamin K

questions.text: Cerebral palsy is a group of motor disorders resulting from non-progressive brain damage, and various types exist based on the nature and distribution of motor impairments among the different types, which form constitutes the most common presentation of cerebral palsy in children?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spastic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common type of cerebral palsy is spastic , characterized by increased muscle tone, stiffness, and scissoring gait due to motor cortex or corticospinal tract damage.
  • ➤ spastic
  • ➤ increased muscle tone, stiffness, and scissoring gait

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric dentist for a routine examination. The parents express concerns about the child's oral health. How many teeth should typically be present in the oral cavity of a 3-year-old?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By 2.5 to 3 years , a child should have a total of 20 primary teeth , completing the full set of temporary teeth in the oral cavity.
  • ➤ 2.5 to 3 years
  • ➤ 20 primary teeth

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient with hepatomegaly, neurological symptoms, change in handwriting, decrease school performance and intention tremors undergoes genetic testing for confirmation of suspected genetic disease. To identify the specific gene mutation associated with this autosomal recessive disorder, which of the following genes should be analyzed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atp7b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson’s disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene , leading to copper accumulation. It presents with a combination of hepatic and neurological symptoms, and treatment involves copper-chelating agents such as D-penicillamine, trientine , or zinc , which reduces copper absorption.
  • ➤ ATP7B gene
  • ➤ copper-chelating agents
  • ➤ D-penicillamine, trientine
  • ➤ zinc

questions.text: During a routine developmental assessment, a pediatrician observes a 3-year-old child demonstrating emerging fine motor skills. The child is asked to draw a circle as part of the evaluation. At which age milestone is it typically expected for a child to successfully draw a circle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A child is typically expected to draw a circle independently by 3 years of age, marking an important milestone in fine motor skill development.

questions.text: In a pediatric hepatology clinic, a 3-month-old infant is presented with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. The pediatrician suspects conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and initiates further investigations. What underlying conditions or disorders should be considered in the differential diagnosis, as they are commonly associated with elevated conjugated bilirubin levels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rotor syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is often associated with conditions like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome, and biliary atresia, presenting with symptoms such as jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine.

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit, a nurse observes a newborn as part of routine assessments and notices certain characteristics related to the eyes. To better understand the normal features of a newborn's pupils and their implications, the nurse initiates a discussion with colleagues. What is the distinctive characteristics of a newborn's pupils?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Constricted

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborn pupils are normally constricted due to the immaturity of the dilator muscle, making dilation difficult in the neonatal period.

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is being evaluated for suspected sepsis, and the healthcare team is considering laboratory markers to aid in diagnosis. Which specific acute phase reactant serves as a valuable marker in the acute-phase response to infection in neonates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CRP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CRP is a reliable acute-phase reactant and serves as a valuable marker for detecting and monitoring neonatal sepsis.

questions.text: In a busy neonatal ward, a paediatrician encounters a newborn with clinical signs suggestive of sepsis. Aware of regional variations in causative agents, the paediatrician initiates a discussion with the medical team to enhance knowledge about neonatal sepsis in the local context. What is considered the most common etiological agent responsible for neonatal sepsis in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acinetobacter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acinetobacter is the most common etiological agent of neonatal sepsis in India, followed by Klebsiella, highlighting the need for stringent infection control measures and antimicrobial stewardship.

questions.text: In a neonatal care unit, a team of healthcare providers is discussing the challenges associated with cold stress in newborns, particularly preterm infants. What is the temperature range of cold stress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Between 36.0 to 36.5 Degree Celsius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cold stress in newborns is defined as a body temperature between 36.0 and 36.5°C. Prompt warming and temperature regulation measures are essential to prevent progression to more severe hypothermia.

questions.text: In a busy labor and delivery suite, a newborn is delivered, and the healthcare team notes that the heart rate is below 100 beats per minute. What immediate steps should be taken to address this bradycardic episode?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bag and mask ventilation (BMV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a newborn with a heart rate <100 bpm, bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is the first and most critical step to address bradycardia.

questions.text: In a pediatric cardiology clinic, a physician is evaluating a newborn with suspected Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and is discussing the diagnostic criteria and clinical features with the medical team. Among the classic components of TOF, which element is not typically considered a defining feature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ASD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot includes RVH, PS, VSD, and an overriding aorta. ASD is not a component of TOF but may be present in associated conditions like Pentalogy of Fallot.

questions.text: A 3 days of baby with features of cyanosis, tachycardia, cardiomegaly was admitted in Nicu and was diagnosed with Trilogy of Fallot. Which is following congenital defect is not a feature of Triology of Fallot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) VSD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trilogy of Fallot consists of RVH, ASD, and PS, and does not include VSD, which is specific to Tetralogy of Fallot.

questions.text: Understanding the classification of congenital heart diseases is pivotal in pediatric cardiology. Among the provided options, which condition represents an Acyanotic congenital heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PDA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) is an acyanotic congenital heart disease that involves left-to-right shunting of blood between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta.

questions.text: Neural tube defects (NTDS) are congenital anomalies that result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during embryonic development. In the context of prenatal screening and diagnosis, determining the best marker for assessing the risk of NTDS is of paramount importance. Considering the various screening modalities available, which specific marker stands out as the most reliable indicator for the assessment of neural tube defect risk during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acetylcholine esterase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetylcholine esterase (AChE) in amniotic fluid is the most specific marker for diagnosing neural tube defects, typically used as a confirmatory test following elevated AFP levels.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a concerned parent brings in their newborn for a thorough examination due to observed physical features. During the examination of your newborn, distinct features such as an anti-mongoloid slant of the eyes, pulmonary stenosis, and undescended testes were observed. These findings can be indicative of a specific syndrome. Can you identify the syndrome associated with these characteristics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Noonan syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noonan syndrome is associated with an anti-mongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, and undescended testes, among other features. It is an autosomal dominant condition.

questions.text: In a developmental pediatrics clinic, parents express curiosity about their child's milestones, particularly regarding the acquisition of fine motor skills such as tying shoelaces. At what age can a child be expected to master the skill of tying shoelaces independently?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 5 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tying shoelaces is a fine motor skill typically achieved by children at 5 years of age, marking a significant milestone in their independence and coordination.

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care setting, healthcare providers often grapple with the challenges of managing preterm infants, considering their unique physiological characteristics. What is the approximate blood volume in a preterm infant, and how does it compare to that of a pre-term newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 90 ml per kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The blood volume in preterm infants is approximately 90–110 ml per kg, reflecting their increased physiological requirements compared to term newborns (60–80 ml per kg).

questions.text: In a pediatric neurology clinic, a concerned parent seeks information about their newborn's skull development, particularly related to the metopic suture. The pediatric neurologist, understanding the importance of addressing parental inquiries, initiates a discussion to elucidate the nuances of skull development in infants. As a parent interested in understanding your newborn's cranial anatomy, you've raised a pertinent question about the metopic suture. The premature fusion of this suture can lead to a distinct skull shape. What term is commonly used to describe the premature fusion of the metopic suture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trigonocephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigonocephaly is the term used to describe the triangular-shaped skull resulting from the premature fusion of the metopic suture. It is a form of craniosynostosis requiring early diagnosis and management.

questions.text: In a pediatric emergency medicine setting, where prompt and effective management of dehydration is crucial, a senior healthcare provider leads a discussion on the optimal fluid choices for severe dehydration in children. In cases of severe dehydration, what is the fluid of choice for resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 100ml/kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In severe dehydration, the fluid of choice for resuscitation is Ringer’s Lactate or Normal Saline, administered at a rate of 100 ml/kg with age-specific adjustments for timing.

questions.text: In a pediatric orthopaedic clinic, a physician is discussing growth and development milestones with parents, specifically focusing on the assessment of proportions in the growing child. On further examination, doctor found that the patient has short trunk dwarfism, and they want to rule out marfan syndrome. What is normal US:LS ratio at 7 year of life is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1:1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 7 years of age, the normal US:LS ratio is approximately 1:1, reflecting balanced growth between the upper and lower segments.

questions.text: In a neonatal neurology seminar, where healthcare professionals are delving into the complexities of neonatal seizures, an expert in the field initiates a discussion to enhance the understanding of seizure types in this vulnerable population. The neurologist poses the following question. As clinicians navigating the intricacies of neonatal care, the identification and management of seizures in newborns are pivotal considerations. When addressing the most common type of seizure observed in neonates, what specific seizure pattern is frequently encountered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Subtle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subtle seizures are the most common type of neonatal seizure. Myoclonic seizures have the worst prognosis, while focal clonic seizures have the best prognosis. The drug of choice for neonatal seizures is phenobarbitone.

questions.text: In a whimsical nutrition seminar aimed at infusing a dose of humor into the serious topic of pediatric malnutrition, a nutritionist engages the audience with a light-hearted question: as we embark on this nutritional adventure, let's delve into the world of chronic malnutrition with a touch of humor. Imagine our little friend, who has been on a long journey of undernutrition, and his body has decided to express its dissatisfaction in a rather comical manner. Which parameter, akin to a picky food critic, tends to be particularly affected in chronic malnutrition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Height for age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic malnutrition , the parameter most significantly affected is height-for-age , leading to stunting. This reflects the long-term consequences of inadequate nutrition during a child’s critical growth periods.
  • ➤ chronic malnutrition
  • ➤ height-for-age

questions.text: In a neonatal care workshop focused on optimizing oxygen therapy for preterm infants, a seasoned neonatologist initiates a discussion on the intricacies of setting target oxygen saturation levels. Considering the vulnerability of these neonates, what is the expected target for peripheral Oxygen Saturation (SPO2) in preterm infants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 85-95%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The target SPO2 for preterm infants is 85-95%, balancing the need to prevent hypoxia while avoiding oxygen toxicity and the risk of Retinopathy of Prematurity.

questions.text: In a developmental paediatrics seminar, where healthcare professionals are exploring the intricacies of infant reflexes and their timeline of disappearance. One fascinating phenomenon is the atonic neck reflex, also known as the 'fencing reflex.' this reflex plays a role in early motor development, but like all good things, it eventually bids adieu. At what approximate age does the atonic neck reflex typically disappear, signifying an essential milestone in a baby's motor development?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Atonic Neck Reflex (ATNR) typically disappears by 6 months of age, aligning with other reflex milestones like the Moro reflex. This signifies the development of voluntary motor control.

questions.text: In a cardiology symposium focused on understanding rare cardiac conditions, a cardiologist sparks curiosity about the unique nutritional aspect associated with keshan disease. Keshan disease stands out as a condition with an unusual nutritional link. This cardiomyopathy, primarily affecting regions with specific environmental factors, is associated with a particular nutrient deficiency. What nutrient deficiency is implicated in the development of keshan disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Selenium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keshan disease is a selenium-deficiency-related cardiomyopathy, emphasizing the importance of selenium in protecting against oxidative stress and maintaining cardiac health.

questions.text: In a pediatric neurology conference exploring various clinical manifestations and diagnostic features, a neurologist introduces a question to unravel the significance of a unique finding. The harrison sulcus. This groove, seen on the chest radiographs of some pediatric patients, has clinical implications. In which condition is harrison sulcus commonly observed, and what does its presence suggest about the underlying pathophysiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Harrison sulcus is a horizontal groove observed in rickets, resulting from weakened rib bones and the pulling force of the diaphragm during respiration.

questions.text: In an endocrinology seminar focusing on the interpretation of imaging findings, a doctor introduces a question to illuminate a distinctive radiographic sign and its clinical implications: as we delve into the realm of radiological interpretations, an intriguing imaging sign often encountered is the 'flag sign.' this particular visual cue can be identified in imaging studies and holds diagnostic significance. In which medical condition is the flag sign commonly observed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flag sign is a distinctive clinical feature of Kwashiorkor, caused by severe protein deficiency, and reflects alternating periods of adequate and inadequate protein intake.

questions.text: In the glittering world of wilson disease, where copper takes center stage, the diagnostic spotlight often turns to serum ceruloplasmin. What's the correct characteristic feature in individuals with wilson disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increase urinary copper excretion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Wilson disease, a hallmark diagnostic feature is increased urinary copper excretion , reflecting the body's inability to regulate copper metabolism.
  • ➤ increased urinary copper excretion

questions.text: In the developmental journey of a child's artistic prowess, the ability to create geometric shapes becomes a notable milestone. As we explore the artistic landscape of childhood, let's delve into the world of cylinders. At what approximate age can a child typically showcase the budding talent of crafting a cylinder, a seemingly simple yet three-dimensional marvel?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 9 year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children typically develop the ability to draw a cylinder, a basic three-dimensional shape, at around 9 years of age.

questions.text: In the perplexing world of congenital infections, the triad of symptoms often plays a crucial role in diagnosis. However, one congenital infection adds a touch of mystery by challenging the traditional triadic narrative. When considering congenital toxoplasmosis, a condition notorious for its varied presentations, which of the following is not classically included in the triad of symptoms associated with this congenital infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Deafness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Deafness is not part of this triad.

questions.text: As we navigate the historical landscape of congenital syphilis, its triad of classic symptoms has been etched into medical lore. However, in the diverse manifestations of this congenital infection, one must question the conventional triadic narrative. When contemplating congenital syphilis, a condition with a storied past and complex presentations, which of the following is not traditionally considered a part of the classic triad of symptoms associated with this congenital infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) PDA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classical triad of congenital syphilis (Hutchinson's Triad) consists of Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and 8th nerve deafness. PDA is not part of this triad.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a distressed couple brings in their 6-month-old infant exhibiting developmental delays, hypotonia, and unusual, sparse, steel-coloured hair & loose abdominal skin. Upon examination, the pediatrician suspects genetic disease. What is the suspected underlying genetic defect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atp7a gene mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menkes disease is caused by a mutation in the Atp7a gene and is characterized by sparse, steel-colored hair, developmental delays, hypotonia, and connective tissue abnormalities due to defective copper transport.

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a newborn present with excessive oral secretions, choking, and cyanosis during feeds. Physical examination reveals a gastric bubble on x-ray & failure to pass ng tube. What is your best diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TEF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of excessive oral secretions, choking, cyanosis during feeds, failure to pass an NG tube, and coiling on X-ray with a gastric bubble is diagnostic of Tracheoesophageal Fistula (TEF).

questions.text: In the realm of pediatric respiratory illnesses, the radiographic features play a pivotal role in diagnosis. In a clinical scenario involving a 3-year-old child presenting with abrupt onset of barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and respiratory distress, the clinician suspects croup. When assessing the child's neck radiograph, a characteristic finding known as the "steeple sign" is identified. What anatomical structure does the steeple sign represent, and what underlying pathology is most likely causing these distinctive radiographic changes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Croup

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The steeple sign, seen on AP neck X-rays, is a hallmark of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), which is caused by subglottic inflammation and narrowing of the airway, commonly due to viral infections.

questions.text: In a routine well-child check-up, a paediatrician observes a Blue-Gray pigmented area on the lower back of a newborn. Recognizing it as a Mongolian spot, the paediatrician explains to the concerned parents that these benign pigmented lesions are common in infants, particularly in certain ethnic groups. The parents inquire about the most frequent location for Mongolian spots.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lumbo sacral

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mongolian spots are most commonly found in the lumbo-sacral region and are benign pigmented lesions that typically fade over time without intervention .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In the preterm neonatal ward, a vigilant paediatrician encounters a term newborn displaying symptoms of bilious vomiting, abdominal distension & blood in stool. The baby was on cow’s feed. What is the best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) NEC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) is a life-threatening condition commonly seen in preterm infants or those fed with cow’s milk formula, characterized by bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and blood in stool.

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a preterm infant born at 28 weeks' gestation exhibits signs of respiratory distress shortly after delivery. The medical team quickly intervenes to provide respiratory support. Recognizing the vulnerability of preterm infants to respiratory complications, the neonatologist reflects on the most common cause of distress in this population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HMD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) is the most common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants due to surfactant deficiency, especially in those born before 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: In a prenatal consultation, a mother diagnosed with bipolar disorder expresses concerns about continuing her lithium medication during pregnancy. The expectant mother seeks guidance regarding the potential risks to her developing baby. The obstetrician explains the association between lithium use during pregnancy and a specific congenital heart defect. Which is the closest best answer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Box shape heart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lithium use during pregnancy increases the risk of Ebstein’s anomaly, characterized by a box-shaped heart due to right atrial enlargement.

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a newborn present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and a heart murmur. Further evaluation reveals total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (tapvc). Which is the commonest type of tapvc?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supracardiac tapvc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Supracardiac TAPVC is the most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, where pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: In a prenatal ultrasound examination, an expectant mother's developing fetus exhibits distinct sonographic features that raise concerns about a congenital anomaly. The image reveals a portion of the abdominal organs within the thoracic cavity, indicated by a hyperechoic mass. Further evaluation confirms the presence of liver and bowel loops within the chest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital diaphragmatic hernia involves herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity through a diaphragmatic defect. It presents prenatally as hyperechoic abdominal contents in the chest and postnatally with severe respiratory distress.

questions.text: In the neonatal unit, a newborn present with persistent respiratory distress and difficulty feeding which decreases on crying. What is the best diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Choanal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral choanal atresia should be suspected in a newborn with respiratory distress and feeding difficulty that improves on crying, as newborns are obligate nose breathers.

questions.text: In the pediatric pulmonology clinic, a 7-year-old child presents with recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis. The parents mention a family history of similar respiratory issues. Considering the clinical presentation, which of the following congenital conditions is most likely responsible for the recurrent infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener syndrome (a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia) is characterized by recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus (dextrocardia on X-ray).

questions.text: In the pediatric otolaryngology clinic, a 4-month-old infant is brought in by concerned parents who describe episodes of noisy breathing, especially during feeding and sleeping. Clinical examination reveals inspiratory stridor, mild retractions, and a flaccid epiglottis on laryngoscopy. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis for the infant's airway obstruction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laryngomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of inspiratory stridor in infants and is characterized by a flaccid, omega-shaped epiglottis seen on laryngoscopy. It is a self-limiting condition.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a 6-month-old infant presents with cough, wheezing, and respiratory distress. The parents report a few days of rhinorrhea and cough preceding the onset of these symptoms. On examination, the infant has tachypnea, bilateral wheezing, and scattered crackles. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely organism for the infant's respiratory distress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory syncitial virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bronchiolitis in infants aged 6 months to 2 years is most commonly caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), presenting with cough, wheezing, tachypnea, and respiratory distress.

questions.text: In a routine newborn examination, a pediatrician detects a heart murmur in a term infant. Further evaluation reveals a left-to-right shunt with increased pulmonary blood flow. The infant is asymptomatic, thriving well, and has no other associated anomalies. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis of the congenital heart disease in this newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VSD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is the most common congenital heart defect and often presents as a left-to-right shunt with increased pulmonary blood flow, detected as a murmur during routine newborn examinations.

questions.text: In the maternity ward, a newborn displays central cyanosis shortly after birth. Physical examination reveals a single loud second heart sound, a continuous murmur, and an absence of respiratory distress. Pulse oximetry readings show a lower oxygen saturation in the lower extremities compared to the upper extremities. Echocardiography confirms parallel great vessels and no communication between the systemic and pulmonary circulations. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis of the congenital cyanotic heart disease in this newborn is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TGA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) is characterized by central cyanosis, a single loud second heart sound, and parallel great vessels, requiring urgent intervention to establish mixing between systemic and pulmonary circulations.

questions.text: A 1-month newborn exhibits profound cyanosis had a single loud second heart sound, a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border, and cardiomegaly on chest x-ray. The infant is also at an increased risk of hypercyanotic episodes (tet spells). Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis of the congenital cyanotic heart disease in this newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TOF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) presents with profound cyanosis, a single loud S2, a harsh systolic murmur, and hypercyanotic episodes (Tet spells). Management includes knee-chest positioning, oxygen, and surgical correction .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In the pediatric emergency department, a 5-year-old child presents with sudden-onset fever, dysphagia, and drooling. The child is sitting in a tripod position and prefers to breathe with the mouth open. On examination, there is notable inspiratory stridor considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute epiglottitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis presents with fever, dysphagia, drooling, tripod positioning, and inspiratory stridor. The hallmark finding is the thumb sign on lateral neck X-ray. Immediate airway management and antibiotics are essential.

questions.text: In the pediatric pulmonology clinic, a 6-month-old infant is brought in by parents concerned about recurrent respiratory infections and poor weight gain despite a voracious appetite. The child has greasy, foul-smelling stools, and physical examination reveals digital clubbing and nasal polyps. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis for this infant's respiratory and gastrointestinal manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis presents with recurrent respiratory infections, poor weight gain, steatorrhea, digital clubbing, and nasal polyps. The sweat chloride test confirms the diagnosis, and management involves addressing respiratory and gastrointestinal complications .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a concerned parent brings in their 8-year-old child who is experiencing involuntary nighttime bedwetting several times a week. The child has a history of successful toilet training during the day and does not report any daytime urinary symptoms. Physical examination and urinalysis reveal no abnormalities. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely treatment for this child's nocturnal enuresis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Motivational or conditioning therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Motivational or conditioning therapy, including bedwetting alarms and behavioral changes, is the first-line treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis in children.

questions.text: In a pediatric genetics’ clinic, a 2-year-old child is brought in by parents who express concerns about delayed developmental milestones and distinct facial features. The child exhibits a flat facial profile, slanted eyes with epicanthic folds, a protruding tongue. Further evaluation reveals hypotonia and ligamentous laxity. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis for this child's developmental delay and physical characteristics & also this condition is the most common non preventable cause of intellectual disability?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Down syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Down syndrome is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and presents with characteristic facial features, developmental delay, hypotonia, and ligamentous laxity.

questions.text: In a pediatric vaccination clinic, a healthcare provider is administering routine vaccinations to a 6-month-old infant. The parent inquiries about the vaccines given via the intradermal route. The healthcare provider explains that most routine vaccines are administered intramuscularly, except for one that is given intradermally. Which of the following vaccines is not typically administered via the intradermal route?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rotavirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BCG and Rabies vaccines can be administered intradermally, IPV is intramuscular or subcutaneous, and Rotavirus vaccine is given orally.

questions.text: During a routine vaccination session, a healthcare provider is about to administer the bacillus Calmette Guérin (BCG) vaccine & measles to an infant. The parent, curious about the vaccine components, asks about the preservative used in the BCG vaccine. What would be the most appropriate response regarding the preservative in the BCG vaccine & measles vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No preservative used

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The BCG and measles vaccines do not contain any preservatives, as they are formulated as freeze-dried live attenuated vaccines and are used immediately after reconstitution.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a parent brings in their 2-year-old child for routine vaccinations. The child has a history of egg allergy, and the parent expresses concern about potential adverse reactions to certain vaccines. Considering the child's egg allergy, which of the following vaccines should be avoided due to the risk of an allergic reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Influenza & yellow fever vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The influenza and yellow fever vaccines should be avoided or used with caution in individuals with severe egg allergies due to the risk of allergic reactions, as these vaccines are produced using egg-based cultures.
  • ➤ influenza
  • ➤ yellow fever vaccines

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 1-year-old child presents for a catch-up vaccination schedule. The child has missed the routine bacillus Calmette Guérin (BCG) vaccine at birth. The healthcare provider explains the importance of BCG vaccination for protection against tuberculosis. Considering the catch-up scenario, when is the catch up for the child to receive the BCG vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The BCG vaccine should be given at birth or up to 1 year of age if the birth dose is missed, as this timeframe ensures the vaccine's efficacy in protecting against severe forms of tuberculosis.
  • ➤ at birth
  • ➤ up to 1 year of age

questions.text: In a neonatal screening program, a healthcare provider is evaluating a newborn for metabolic disorders. The laboratory uses the jeryl lynn strain for a specific diagnostic test. Considering the clinical scenario, what is the primary purpose of utilizing the jeryl lynn strain in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mumps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Jeryl Lynn strain is specifically used for the mumps component of the MMR vaccine, ensuring effective prevention against mumps infections.
  • ➤ Jeryl Lynn strain

questions.text: In a pediatric public health clinic, parents inquire about the significance of world rabies day. The healthcare provider explains the importance of raising awareness about rabies prevention and control. Considering the clinical scenario, when do you celebrate world rabies day?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 28thSeptember

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ World Rabies Day is observed annually on 28th September to promote rabies awareness and prevention globally.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a deep dog bite on the face. Considering the potential exposure to rabies, what is the most appropriate initial dose of human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) and equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) for post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 IU & 40 IU

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For rabies post-exposure prophylaxis, the dose is 20 IU/kg for human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) and 40 IU/kg for equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG).

questions.text: A 6-year-old Rahul came with complaints of dog bite. On examination it was a category 3 bite. But one thing Rahul forgot to tell that - i have been bitten by a dog last year also & i had taken full prophylaxis for that, today again i got bitten by a dog – what is the schedule of Arv should I follow ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Day 0,3

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A day-old newborn with hepatosplenomegaly with periventricular calcifications and hearing loss. What is the best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CMV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital CMV infection is characterized by periventricular calcifications , hearing loss , and hepatosplenomegaly . It is the most common cause of congenital sensorineural hearing loss.
  • ➤ CMV infection
  • ➤ periventricular calcifications
  • ➤ hearing loss
  • ➤ hepatosplenomegaly

questions.text: A 10-year-old came for routine vaccination, which vaccine should be given to the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TT/TD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 10 years of age , the child should receive a TT/TD booster to maintain protection against tetanus and diphtheria.
  • ➤ 10 years of age
  • ➤ TT/TD booster

questions.text: Water lily sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydatid liver cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The water lily sign is a diagnostic feature of hydatid liver cysts , seen when the inner cyst layer detaches and floats within the cystic fluid.
  • ➤ water lily sign
  • ➤ hydatid liver cysts

questions.text: Identify the image and choose the best answer:

options.label: A
options.text: KF ring is seen in Wilson disease

questions.correct_answer: A. KF ring is seen in Wilson disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) KF ring is seen in Wilson disease

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings are a diagnostic feature of Wilson disease and result from copper deposition in the cornea.

  • ➤ Wilson disease

questions.text: A 4-year-old child came with complaints of bowing of legs and widening of wrist. On further examination, the child appears to have low serum calcium with the image shown as follows. Choose the best answer:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickets is characterized by bowing of legs , widening of wrists , and laboratory findings such as low calcium and vitamin D deficiency .
  • ➤ Rickets
  • ➤ bowing of legs
  • ➤ widening of wrists
  • ➤ low calcium
  • ➤ vitamin D deficiency

questions.text: A 10-day-old baby came with blue cornea. On further ophthalmologic evaluation, baby found to have blue cornea with photophobia and lacrimation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of blue cornea, photophobia, and lacrimation in a newborn is diagnostic of congenital glaucoma .
  • ➤ blue cornea, photophobia, and lacrimation
  • ➤ congenital glaucoma

questions.text: A 3-year-old female baby came with cough and fast breathing for 5 days. Chest X-ray was done which showed a finding in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Croup

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The steeple sign on a chest X-ray is diagnostic of croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) , with parainfluenza virus being the most common cause.
  • ➤ steeple sign
  • ➤ croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis)
  • ➤ parainfluenza virus

questions.text: What are the vitamin K dependent clotting factors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) II, VII, IX, X

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vitamin K-dependent clotting factors are II, VII, IX, and X , critical for proper blood coagulation.
  • ➤ vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
  • ➤ II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: A child has been diagnosed with scurvy. The reason for bleeding manifestations/ecchymosis in vitamin C deficiency is due to:

options.label: B
options.text: Due to lack of sunlight exposure

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Defective collagen formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bleeding manifestations in scurvy are due to defective collagen formation , resulting from vitamin C deficiency.
  • ➤ scurvy
  • ➤ defective collagen formation

questions.text: Elevated sweat chloride test is done in which disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is diagnosed by an elevated sweat chloride test , with levels ≥60 mmol/L being diagnostic.

  • ➤ elevated sweat chloride test

questions.text: A 5-year-old baby came with suspected case of IEM. During the urine workup, the junior resident on duty found that there was darkening of urine on standing. What is the best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alkaptonuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria presents with darkening of urine on standing , ochronotic pigmentation, and ochronotic arthritis. Nitisinone is the drug of choice for treatment.
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria
  • ➤ darkening of urine on standing
  • ➤ Nitisinone

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby presented with perioral rash/perivaginal rash with history of delayed wound healing. Which is the most common nutrient deficiency in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency is the most common cause of perioral and perivaginal rash with delayed wound healing , particularly in conditions like acrodermatitis enteropathica .
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency
  • ➤ perioral and perivaginal rash
  • ➤ delayed wound healing
  • ➤ acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: A 7-year-old child came dehydrated with blood sugar 550 mg/dL with fruity odor breath. Urine for ketones was advised which came out to be 3+. Which is the best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diabetic ketoacidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of hyperglycemia , ketonuria , and fruity odor on breath is diagnostic of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) .
  • ➤ hyperglycemia
  • ➤ ketonuria
  • ➤ fruity odor on breath
  • ➤ diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)

questions.text: A term baby with a body weight of 15 kg and height of 100 cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient if the K value is 0.4?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 mL/min/1.73 m2 BSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Schwartz formula (eGFR= K × Height / Serum Creatinine )
  • ➤ The Schwartz formula
  • ➤ )
  • ➤ is used to estimate glomerular filtration rate in children. For this patient, the eGFR is 40 mL/min/1.73 m² BSA.
  • ➤ estimate glomerular filtration rate
  • ➤ 40 mL/min/1.73 m² BSA.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) West syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACTH is the drug of choice for West syndrome (infantile spasms), a severe form of epilepsy in infants characterized by spasms, hypsarrhythmia, and developmental regression.

  • ➤ West syndrome

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a nurse assesses a newborn's overall well-being using the apgar score, a quick and standardized evaluation performed at one and five minutes after birth. Considering the components of the apgar score, which of the following is not a factor included in this assessment tool?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Respiratory rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score evaluates five parameters: heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and skin color. Respiratory rate is not a component ; instead, respiratory effort is assessed.
  • ➤ Apgar score
  • ➤ heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and skin color. Respiratory rate is not a component

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is born with a birth weight of 850 grams. To categorize the degree of prematurity and guide appropriate medical interventions, the healthcare team refers to the extremely low birth weight (elbw) cutoff. What is the generally accepted elbw cutoff?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 500 grams; facilitating prompt respiratory support

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 750 grams; guiding nutritional interventions

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 1,500 grams; indicating the need for developmental follow-up

questions.correct_answer: C. Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW) is defined as a birth weight of less than 1,000 grams. These infants require specialized care due to their high risk of complications .
  • ➤ .
